title: Lab 5 — Social Engineering Analysis: Recognize, Respond, Teach
tagline: Analyze synthetic scenarios to recognize patterns, explain why they work, and practice safe responses—without real brands or live interaction.
result_framing: This is not a quiz. Use the model comparison to reflect on patterns and reasoning. Different answers can still be defensible if your safety response is sound and your explanation is clear.
attacker_goal_options: Click a link / open a page
Share information (details, codes, or sensitive context)
Create a new communication channel (move to another number/app)
Lower defenses (keep the target engaged and compliant)
shortcut_options: Binary choice traps (YES/NO) that bypass reflection
response_options: Do not engage; verify independently using known channels; report
Pause and consult policy or supervisor; document; report
End contact; start a new contact using a verified directory number; report
Do not click/reply; open the official app/site directly; report
Assume it may be a test or scam; treat it calmly; report without blame
teaching_guardrail_options: Use fictional organizations and neutral wording
Avoid realistic templates that could be reused
No credential entry, links, or live interaction
Focus on reporting and verification steps
Avoid victim-blaming language; emphasize situational pressure
Discuss multiple safe responses (not a single magic move)

scenarios.notes: A message arrives at the start of a busy day. It requests immediate action and implies consequences.
scenarios.artifact:
Subject: Required Action Today

Your account is missing a required confirmation step. Please complete the update immediately to avoid restricted access.

If you have questions, reply to this message so we can assist.

focus.discussion_prompt: What makes this feel urgent even without specifics?

answers.attacker_goal: Click a link / open a page
deconstruction: A deadline without verifiable details pushes action before reflection.
A convenient next step (reply/click) moves control to the sender.
answers.safe_response: Do not click or reply. Verify independently using a known internal portal or published support channel. Report using the organization’s process.
answers.teaching_note: Keep language generic and brand-neutral. Teach the pattern: urgency + vague consequences + convenient next step. Practice “verify independently” as a default.

scenarios.notes: A caller claims to be support and asks for confirmation due to 'suspicious activity.'
scenarios.artifact:
Call summary:
A caller says they are from support. They mention 'unusual access' and ask you to confirm recent sign-ins and provide a verification code to 'lock down the account.'

focus.discussion_prompt: Why do verification codes feel safe to share when stressed?

answers.attacker_goal: Share information (details, codes, or sensitive context)
deconstruction: Borrowed authority lowers skepticism and speeds compliance.
A crisis frame makes risky actions feel protective.
A “small” data request (a code) can enable a larger compromise.
answers.safe_response: End the call politely. Initiate a new call using a verified directory number. Never share verification codes on inbound contact. Report the attempt.
answers.teaching_note: Use summaries rather than realistic role-play scripts. Reinforce: inbound contact is untrusted; verify via known channels.

scenarios.notes: Short messages compress context and invite quick replies.
scenarios.artifact:
Text message:
Unusual activity detected. Reply YES to confirm this was you or NO to secure your account now.

focus.discussion_prompt: What does the YES/NO choice prevent you from doing?

answers.attacker_goal: Create a new communication channel (move to another number/app)
shortcuts: Binary choice traps (YES/NO) that bypass reflection
deconstruction: Binary options reduce reflection and bypass verification.
Fear pushes action to avoid harm.
A reply can confirm the number is active and invite follow-on steps.
answers.safe_response: Do not reply. Check the account independently using a known app or official website. Report the message if needed.
answers.teaching_note: Keep examples generic and short. Emphasize that replying can escalate risk. Teach: pause, verify independently, report—without blame.

scenarios.notes: This scenario exploits goodwill and social obligation rather than fear.
scenarios.artifact:
Subject: Quick help before deadline

I’m locked out of a shared workspace and need the files within the hour. Can you log in and download them for me? It would really save me.

focus.discussion_prompt: Why does helping feel safe even when it violates policy?

deconstruction: The request frames policy-breaking as kindness, shifting identity to “helper.”
A deadline discourages verification and alternatives.
It asks for an action that transfers access or data without needing credentials.
answers.safe_response: Do not log in on someone else’s behalf. Offer safe alternatives (official reset/support steps) and report if suspicious.
answers.teaching_note: Emphasize that policies protect people. Teach students they can be helpful while refusing unsafe actions.
